David Moore, head of the structured- rates unit, also left the firm, a person briefed on the matter said last month.

entry.author: By Tom Mulier
entry.headline: General Mills Expects Food Commodity Prices to Rise 5% a Year
entry.body:
General Mills Inc. Chief Executive Officer Ken Powell said the Cheerios maker expects food commodity prices to continue rising about 5 percent annually as demand from emerging markets increases.

Commodity prices have gained about 5 percent to 6 percent a year for more than a decade, he said today at a press conference with joint venture partner Nestle SA in Orbe, Switzerland.

If you average it out, it''s about 5 percent, and so we think this is likely to continue, he told journalists, saying the company has an assumption of mid-single digit input cost inflation. We were planning for this.

General Mills, based in Minneapolis, Minnesota, has been trying to offset higher input costs as much as possible by eliminating waste and improving productivity, Powell said. The company, which raised prices on about a quarter of its cereal products in November, aims to minimize price increases, he said.

The consumer is still being pretty careful, Powell said. Consumer confidence is rising, but slowly, and it''s still pretty low.

Nestle, based in Vevey, Switzerland, and General Mills today inaugurated a cereal research center for their Cereal Partners Worldwide joint venture.

entry.author: By John Detrixhe and Sapna Maheshwari
entry.headline: Goldman Issues Debt in Its Biggest Sale Since 2009
entry.body:
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. sold $3.5 billion of bonds in its biggest dollar-denominated sale since 2009, taking advantage of the lowest-ever short-term financial company borrowing costs relative to longer-term yields.

The bank, which holds the record for the highest profit earned by a U.S. securities firm, issued $1 billion of three- year notes that yield 100 basis points more than the three-month London interbank offered rate, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The New York-based company''s $2.5 billion of 3.625 percent, 5-year fixed-rate securities pay a 158 basis-point spread to similar-maturity Treasuries, the data show.

The gap in yields between financial company bonds due in one to three years and those maturing in seven to 10 years widened to 3.18 percentage points on Jan. 31, the greatest gap on record, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch index data going back to 1996.

They are definitely taking advantage of the steep yield curve, said Nicholas Finkelman, who helps oversee $3.5 billion of bonds as a money manager at New York-based Ryan Labs Inc. This general area is great for issuers to lock in low yields.

The fifth-biggest U.S. bank by assets last month sold $2.5 billion of 6.25 percent, 30-year bonds, Bloomberg data show.

Yield Curve

The yield curve has steepened amid signs that economic growth is gaining momentum and as the Federal Reserve has kept its benchmark overnight rate in a range of zero to 0.25 percent for two years. Companies in the U.S. added more workers than forecast in January, data from a private report showed today.

The new issue is the biggest from Goldman Sachs since March 12, 2009, when the bank sold $5 billion of debt under the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.''s Temporary Liquidity Guarantee Program. It''s the largest dollar-denominated sale without government assistance since a $4.05 billion three-part offering in January 2004, according to Goldman Sachs.

The new offering is cheap, compared with outstanding similar-maturity debt, said Finkelman.

Goldman Sachs issued $2.25 billion of five-year, 3.7 percent notes in July that paid 205 basis points, or 2.05 percentage points, more than benchmarks, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

The spread environment continues to be extremely favorable for issuers, Finkelman said.

Goldman Sachs''s new notes will likely be rated A1 by Moody''s Investors Service and A+ by Standard Poor''s, Bloomberg data show. Libor is the rate banks charge each other on loans.

entry.author: By Nidaa Bakhsh and Aaron Clark
entry.headline: Exxon Says Blower Trips Offline at Joliet Refinery
entry.body:
Exxon Mobil Corp. reported that a blower associated with a unit tripped offline at its Joliet oil refinery in Illinois.

The cause of the incident is being investigated and production wasn''t affected, Kevin Allexon, a company spokesman, said in an e-mail.

Sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide were among the gases released at about 10 p.m. local time yesterday through the flare system, according to a filing with the Illinois Emergency Management Agency.

The refinery has the capacity to process 248,000 barrels of crude oil a day, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

entry.author: By Natalie Obiko Pearson
entry.headline: Morgan Stanley Denies Report It Has Been Hired by Gamesa
entry.body:
Morgan Stanley denied a report by Mint that it has been hired by Spanish wind-turbine manufacturer Gamesa Corp. Tecnologica SA to explore the possibility of acquiring wind-power assets in India.

We deny that Morgan Stanley''s been hired by Gamesa, spokesman Michael Wang said by telephone from London. The report isn''t true.

The Mint report cited two people, including an executive at the local unit of the New York-based firm, whom it didn''t identify by name.

entry.author: By Nidaa Bakhsh
entry.headline: Chevron Phillips May Flare at Port Arthur as Valero Shuts Units
entry.body:
Chevron Phillips Chemical Co. may flare gas at its Port Arthur site in Texas because its customer Valero Energy Corp., which uses the fuel, will shut units for maintenance, according to a filing with state regulators.

Valero is planning to shut down all but 3 or 4 of its operating units starting today, according to the filing with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality. The filing didn''t say which plants would be idled.

Chevron Phillips''s ethylene unit produces feedstock for the Valero plant, according to the filing. Chevron has to flare this raw material as no storage is available at both sites, the filing showed.

Valero''s Port Arthur refinery can process 310,000 barrels of crude oil a day, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

entry.author: By Kateryna Choursina
entry.headline: Chevron Seeks to Invest in Shale Gas in Ukraine, Azarov Says
entry.body:
Chevron Corp. may invest in shale-gas extraction in Ukraine, Prime Minister Mykola Azarov said.

Chevron wants to invest in extraction of shale gas in Ukraine, Azarov said today at the opening of a weekly government meeting in the capital, Kiev. The company''s top management yesterday met with the government, he said.

Ukraine seeks to develop gas deposits trapped in shale rock as it aims to reduce its dependency on imported fuels. The country gets about half of its energy needs from Russia and price disputes between the neighbors has twice interrupted gas flows to the West since 2006. Russia ships about 80 percent of the fuels it sends to Europe via Ukraine.

Shale gas fields are difficult to develop and require large investments, the prime minister said, without specifying amounts needed.

entry.author: By Katrina Nicholas
entry.headline: JPMorgan Said to Plan Sale of Centro Properties Debt
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase Co. is holding an auction to find buyers for $143 million in loans owed to it by Australia''s Centro Properties Group, according to a person familiar with the matter.

The New York-based bank is seeking investors for senior portions of the loans, denominated in both U.S. and Australian dollars, the person said, asking not to be identified as the details are private. The auction will be held today at 5:00 p.m. London time, the person said.

Centro, a Melbourne-based shopping mall owner that had A$18.4 billion ($18.6 billion) of debt as of June 30, ceded control to creditors in 2008 as property prices slumped and debt became harder to refinance.

Australia New Zealand Banking Group Ltd. sold about A$700 million of debt owed to it by the company in November, a person familiar with the matter said at the time. The sale included A$495 million of senior debt priced at 63.5 cents in the dollar, said the person, who asked not to be named because the information was private.

Commonwealth Bank of Australia also said in November that it sold A$110 million of Centro''s debt for about 56.5 cents in the dollar.

Noelle Waugh, a Sydney-based spokeswoman for JPMorgan, declined to comment when contacted by telephone today.

The Australian Financial Review reported details of JPMorgan''s planned sale earlier today, citing loan traders it didn''t identify.

entry.author: By Ashley Lutz
entry.headline: Microsoft Sells $2.25 Billion of Debt in Three-Part Offering
entry.body:
Microsoft Corp. sold $2.25 billion of debt in three parts, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

The company sold $750 million of 5-year notes paying 38 basis points more than similar-maturity U.S. Treasuries, $500 million of 10-year debt paying 48 basis points more than benchmarks and $1 billion of 30-year bonds at a 68 basis-point spread, the data show. A basis point is 0.01 of a percentage point.

entry.author: By Jeff Kearns and Cecile Vannucci
entry.headline: JPMorgan Put Volume Jumps to Double Average on One Bet
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase Co. put-option volume surged as an investor took out protection from the bank''s shares dropping through January, according to Joe Kunkle, founder of OptionsHawk.com.

The investor bought 25,000 January 2012 $40 puts at 1:19 p.m. in New York and sold 50,000 January 2012 $30 puts, a so- called spread strategy possibly used as insurance against a retreat, Kunkle said. The strategy profits most if the shares fall to $30. The shares haven''t closed below $40 since Dec. 20 or fallen under $30 since April 2009. JPMorgan rose 1 cent to $45.46 at 4 p.m. in New York.

These spreads are often used as hedges to long equity exposure, Kunkle said.

The cost of buying insurance in the U.S. options market has fallen toward the lowest levels since 2007, with the Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index dropping to 15.45 on Dec. 22. Shares of New York-based JPMorgan have rallied two straight years, and the company posted a record fourth-quarter profit of $4.83 billion last month.

More than 122,000 puts to sell the stock changed hands, double the four-week average and almost three times the number of calls to buy. The January $30 puts were the most-traded contracts and accounted for almost half of all put volume.

entry.author: By Paul Burkhardt
entry.headline: Exxon Beaumont Chemical Plant Has Equipment Failure
entry.body:
Exxon Mobil Corp. reported that equipment failure caused emissions at its Beaumont, Texas, chemical plant, according to a filing with state regulators.

The plant flared gases as a result of the incident, which began at 1:59 p.m. local time yesterday and lasted about 45 minutes, according to the filing with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.

entry.author: By Scott Anthony
entry.headline: Procter & Gamble and Innovation in Asia
entry.body:
"Asia Fueling Global Innovation." That was the theme of the 2-hour panel discussion I moderated as part of a full-day ceremony celebrating the groundbreaking of Procter Gamble''s SGD 250m Innovation Centre in Singapore.

As promised, I asked Bruce Brown, PG''s CTO, one of the questions readers submitted last week: "As you look forward into the future what do you see as PG''s largest challenges, as seen through your eyes as CTO?" Brown noted three specific challenges.

First, the general challenge of growth. PG is about an $80 billion company. It typically shoots for 4 to 6 percent organic growth every year. Historically, 80 percent of its growth comes from innovation. Run the numbers and you''re looking at close to $4 billion dollars in growth, every year. As a point of comparison, Hasbro an 87-year-old company has annual revenues of $4 billion. So PG has to create a new Hasbro, every year. This is a challenge when realizing some of that potential requires smartly re-thinking core systems and structures. (Brown and I are working on a more expansive piece on this very topic.)

Second, Brown highlighted how PG has to deal with the fact that 50 percent of its RD scientists will reach retirement age in the next few years. While that presents a clear challenge retaining the awesome accumulated knowledge of these scientists it also creates an opportunity to make sure that RD talent is balanced with global opportunities.

Third, PG has to deal with sustainability issues. It has publicly announced goals to reduce its dependence on petroleum and to increase its use of recycled and renewable materials. He noted how Singapore Agency for Science, Technology Research (A*STAR) has told PG that sustainability is "no longer a program, it is part of how we do our work."

Brown''s remarks set off a fascinating back-and-forth among the panel about some of the general challenges facing companies in Asia and globally. At the end of the day''s wide-ranging discussion, I shared the eight phrases that had stuck with me:

"For and amongst consumers." Bruce Brown used this phrase to describe how PG will achieve its stated goal of serving 5 billion consumers by the year 2015 (an increase of 800 million from today). Brown described how localizing research activities is a key component of that strategy. "The Red Dot." A*STAR Managing Director Low Teck Seng used that phrase to describe how Singapore appears on a map. He described how the country''s small size allowed it to be more nimble, reminding the audience that sometimes constraints can foster innovation. "Florence." PG RD VP for Asia Maurizio Marchesini noted similarities between Singapore and Florence during the Italian Renaissance, with free-flowing ideas and disciplines colliding. He and I both noted how solving tough problems requires this kind of interdisciplinary co-location where people work together in new ways. "Simplifying technology and new business models." Those are the two ingredients Shamik Dasgupta, the regional head of Medtronic''s Cardiac Rhythm Management business unit, described as vital for driving disruptive growth in markets like India and China. "Non-consumption." National University of Singapore Professor CC Hang used that term to answer the question of where there are the greatest opportunities for disruptive growth in Asia. He noted how there were more than 20 million electric bikes sold in China in 2010, many of them to women or other non-traditional vehicle purchasers. "As common as possible, as different as needed." That''s how Deb Henretta, the head of PG''s Asia business, described how she thought about approaching Asian markets. She pointed out some of the real differences between consumers in different markets. For example, "beauty" means fair skin to many Asian consumers and tanned skin to many U.S. consumers. But using scale where appropriate can help companies like PG realize its full global potential. "Non-obvious disruptions." Marchesini didn''t quite use this term, but it was how I described an example he provided. He described how PG sells a product under the Downy brand that provides long-lasting scent benefits to clothes using microcapsules. In markets like the Philippines, this technology allows PG to bring scent benefits to consumers who can''t afford higher end perfumes. "Re-frame." Henretta noted how important re-framing was to manage many of the challenges inherent in mastering innovation in today''s economy. One intriguing thing she noted, "You have to make sure your workforce reflects the consumers you are going to serve."

It was great to see the energy around the topic, and the passion that the six leaders had for Asia''s innovation potential.And, at the end of the day after Brown, Henretta, and key government officials officially broke ground on the Innovation Centre, I got a chance to participate in lo hei the ceremonial tossing of a salad to bring good fortune in the coming Chinese Lunar New Year.

entry.author: By Sapna Maheshwari and John Detrixhe
entry.headline: Microsoft May Use Debt Sale to Reward Shareholders
entry.body:
Microsoft Corp., the world''s largest software maker, plans to sell $2.25 billion of debt as soon as today as investment-grade companies tap the corporate bond market to reward shareholders.

Proceeds may be used for working capital, stock buybacks and acquisitions, the Redmond, Washington-based company said today in a regulatory filing. Microsoft is offering 5-, 10- and 30-year senior unsecured debt, according to a person familiar with the transaction.

2011 is going to be more the year of the shareholder than the year of the bondholder, said Tom Murphy, a money manager who helps oversee about $23 billion of investment-grade credit at Columbia Management in Minneapolis. Some companies are going to be taking that treasure trove of cash they have and rewarding shareholders, whether it''s through share buybacks, dividends, or doing strategic MA transactions.

Credit quality will weaken among investment-grade issuers this year as companies facing limited business opportunities, take advantage of relatively low interest rates to repurchase stock, according to Janney Montgomery Scott LLC. Bonds issued by Microsoft in its last U.S. offering in September have tumbled, while the company''s shares have climbed 14.4 percent.

In today''s offering, a $750 million portion of 5-year notes may pay 38 basis points more than similar-maturity Treasuries, $500 million of 10-year debt may pay 48 basis points more than benchmarks and $1 billion of 30-year bonds may pay a spread of 68 basis points, said the person familiar with the offering, who declined to be identified because terms aren''t set.

Lowest Coupons

The extra yield investors demand to own industrial investment-grade debt instead of Treasuries fell to 137 basis points on Jan. 24, the tightest spread since May, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch index data. The spread was 138 basis points yesterday.

Microsoft, one of four non-financial U.S. companies with AAA ratings, issued $4.75 billion of debt in September, including 3- and 5-year notes that set records for the lowest coupons for those maturities.

The offering included $1 billion of 3 percent, 10-year notes that priced at 99.14 cents on the dollar to yield 55 basis points more than similar-maturity Treasuries, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The notes have dropped to 93.1 cents as of yesterday to yield 3.86 percent, or a spread of 36.5 basis points, according to Trace, the bond-price reporting system of the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority.

Windows, Xbox

The company''s 10-year notes lost 5.8 percent since their first full day of trading on Sept. 23, compared with the 1.73 percent loss on its $1.75 billion of 1.625 percent, 5-year notes, Bloomberg data show. Bonds rated AAA have lost 2.82 percent since then while overall investment-grade bonds have declined 1.4 percent, Bank of America Merrill Lynch index data show.

The maker of Windows and Xbox repurchased $5 billion of shares and declared $1.3 billion of dividends in the quarter ended Dec. 31, the company said in a Jan. 27 earnings call.

The Microsoft bonds fell because the extra yield the debt pays relative to Treasuries offers little protection as a shock absorber to rising interest rates, said William Larkin, a fixed income portfolio manager in Salem, Massachusetts, at Cabot Money Management, which manages $500 million.

Super Expensive''

I would look at this as super expensive, Larkin said in a telephone interview. As inflation expectations shift and as Treasuries sell off, basically Microsoft bonds will lose value.

Bank of America Corp. and Credit Suisse Group AG are managing today''s offering, said the person familiar with the issue. Today''s filing didn''t include the size or maturities of the sale.

Investment-grade issuers are beginning to re-leverage their balance sheets after cutting debt in 2008 through early 2010, Guy LeBas, strategist and economist at Janney Montgomery Scott wrote in the broker-dealer''s 2011 outlook on Dec. 20.

Corporate cash balances are at record highs, close to 7 percent of total assets, Barclays Capital said in its global credit outlook report for 2011.

I don''t necessarily think it''s such a terrible thing for us, because we''re starting from such a position of strength from a balance sheet perspective, Columbia Management''s Murphy said of bond sales fueling buybacks and acquisitions.

AAA Rating

Standard Poor''s and Moody''s Investors Service also rank Exxon Mobil Corp., Johnson Johnson and Automatic Data Processing Inc. as AAA, or an equivalent Aaa, the same level they assign to U.S. government debt.

Kimberly-Clark Corp., the maker of Huggies Diapers and Viva paper towels, sold $700 million of bonds on Jan. 27 that may be used to buy back common stock, fund the company''s pension plans, and redeem outstanding commercial paper, according to a statement from the Dallas-based company.

Moody''s assigned an Aaa to the Microsoft offering, the ratings company said today in a note.

entry.author: By David McQuaid
entry.headline: Goldman''s Dibelius Says Poland Merits Fiscal Trust, Gazeta Says
entry.body:
Poland''s fiscal track record may not be fully appreciated and the current government has done enough so far to earn financial markets'' trust, Alexander Dibelius, head of Goldman Sachs Group Inc.''s operations in Germany, Austria and central and eastern Europe, was quoted today as saying in an interview in Gazeta Wyborcza.

Dibelius told the newspaper he would buy Polish bonds, for which Goldman recently became a primary dealer. He said Polish stocks may become more volatile if government plans to cut transfers to private pension funds weaken the role of domestic institutional investors, Gazeta reported.

Click here for web link

entry.author: By Andrea Tan
entry.headline: Morgan Stanley Urges New York Judge to Dismiss Singapore Investors'' Suit
entry.body:
Morgan Stanley, accused by a group of Singapore investors of fraudulently wiping out their $154.7 million investment, urged a Manhattan judge to dismiss the lawsuit, arguing New York isn''t an appropriate place for trial.

The investors had agreed that any dispute relating to their purchase of securities would be resolved in Singapore, Morgan Stanley said in a filing in federal court in Manhattan yesterday.

This court should honor the contractual obligation, Morgan Stanley said. In addition, this case has no nexus to the United States, the bank said

The complaint by 18 Singapore investors, who seek a judge''s permission to sue on behalf of all purchasers of Morgan Stanley''s Pinnacle Notes, alleged the bank created a classic bait and switch scheme secretly designed to benefit Morgan Stanley at the customers'' expense.

Morgan Stanley, based in New York, fraudulently induced the investors into buying the notes, which the bank intentionally and materially misrepresented as safe and conservative, according to the lawsuit filed on Oct. 25.

Several Morgan Stanley units created the scheme to redirect funds into the bank''s own coffers, the investors including the Singapore Government Staff Credit Cooperative Society Ltd. said in the complaint. There may be, at minimum, thousands of class members, the investors said.

Morgan Stanley created collateralized debt obligations, a debt security that''s usually backed by bonds, or corporate loans, and failed to inform the investors that it was a counter- party to the agreements, the investors claimed. For each dollar the investors lost, the bank gained a dollar, the investors said.

Morgan Stanley entities stood on both sides of the agreements, the investors claimed.

Morgan Stanley said the suit should also be thrown out because the Monetary Authority of Singapore investigated the sale of structured financial products and created a resolution system.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. in July agreed to pay $550 million to settle a U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit over claims it misled investors in CDOs linked to subprime mortgages. The bank, which said it made a mistake and marketing materials for the instruments had incomplete information, didn''t admit to any wrongdoing as part of the settlement.

The Monetary Authority of Singapore banned banks from selling the structured investments in 2009 following claims by investors that they were misled on products. The authority lifted the ban on 10 financial institutions last year after they boosted internal procedures of their advisory services across all investment products.

The case is Dandong et al v. Pinnacle Performance Ltd. et al, 10-08086, U.S. District Court, Southern District of New York (Foley Square).

entry.author: By Gene Laverty
entry.headline: Exxon Mobil to Shut Unit at Baton Rouge Refinery
entry.body:
Exxon Mobil Corp. is starting a turnaround on a unit at the Baton Rouge, Louisiana, refinery, Kevin Allexon, a company spokesman, said in an e-mail.

Allexon, who is based in Fairfax, Virginia, declined to provide more information until work begins. Earlier, the company said on a community hot line that it would shut a unit for routine maintenance.

The refinery processes domestic crudes from Louisiana, Texas, Mississippi and Alaska, according to the company''s website. It also imports crude from Mexico, the North Sea, West Africa, South America, Central America and the Arabian Gulf.

The refinery, next to the Mississippi River, can process 503,000 barrels of oil a day, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

entry.author: By Aaron Clark and Leela Landress
entry.headline: Exxon Starts Turbine at Beaumont, Expects Effect on Production
entry.body:
Exxon Mobil Corp., the largest U.S. oil company, expects output to be affected as it starts a cogen turbine at its Beaumont refinery in Texas, said Kevin Allexon, a company spokesman.

We anticipate some impact to production, Allexon, who is based in Fairfax, Virginia, said in an e-mail today. The company reported in a message on a community hot line that conditions required flaring.

Refinery outages can increase prices for refined products as refiners turn to spot markets to help them meet supply contracts. Operational disruptions can also depress prices for crude oil because less feedstock is needed.

The plant can process 359,100 barrels of crude a day, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

entry.author: By Greg Chang
entry.headline: Goldman Sachs Near Buy of Top U.S. Applebee Franchisee, WSJ Says
entry.body:
Goldman Sachs''s GS Capital Partners is close to buying Apple American Group LLC from Weston Presidio Capital, to gain the biggest U.S. franchisee of Applebee''s Neighborhood Grill Bar, the Wall Street Journal reported.

The purchase may be valued at several hundred million dollars, the WSJ said.

entry.author: By Martin Z. Braun
entry.headline: JPMorgan May Seek $778 Million From Alabama County Over Suits
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase Co. said it will seek at least $778 million from Jefferson County, Alabama, if it loses lawsuits brought by companies that insured the county''s defaulted sewer debt.

JPMorgan, which underwrote $3 billion of the debt sales and sold the county derivatives to lower its borrowing costs, is fighting claims filed by Syncora Guarantee Inc. and a unit of Assured Guaranty Ltd. in New York state court.

The bond insurers accuse the bank of concealing payments of $3 million to friends of county commissioners in order to win business. They also said the bank didn''t disclose an engineering report saying the sewer system wouldn''t be able to pay its debt.

JPMorgan demands that Jefferson County agree to indemnify and hold JPMorgan harmless for any losses or costs, including attorney''s fees and expenses sustained by JPMorgan, wrote Mary Beth Forshaw, an attorney at Simpson Thatcher Bartlett LLP representing JPMorgan, in a letter to the County Commission.

The existence of the letter, dated Jan. 31, was previously reported by the Birmingham News. Justin Perras, a JPMorgan spokesman, declined to comment.

Syncora and Assured took JPMorgan to court after Jefferson County''s refinancing of sewer debt issued in 2002 and 2003 collapsed during the credit crisis and almost bankrupted the county. Syncora insured about $1.2 billion of the sewer debt and a $165 million surety policy. Assured provided almost $400 million in coverage.

In response to a lawsuit from Jefferson County, the bank said the county took on too much debt and knew the financing had risks. Payments to friends of the commissioners were directed by the county officials and disclosed in letters to them, according to the bank.

entry.author: By Nidaa Bakhsh
entry.headline: Exxon Mobil Shuts Units at U.K.''s Fawley Oil Refinery
entry.body:
Exxon Mobil Corp. shut two processing units at Fawley, the U.K.''s largest refinery, for about six weeks of planned maintenance from today.

The refinery will shut down one of its pipestills (primary distillation units) and one of the powerformers, the company said in a statement on its website today. The work is expected to continue throughout February and on to mid-March.

The refinery can process about 320,000 barrels of crude oil a day and supplies 15 percent of Britain''s petroleum products, according to the country''s Petroleum Industry Association. Refiners regularly halt equipment for inspections and repairs to prevent problems and ensure efficient operations.

Powerformers make blending components for gasoline. Exxon Mobil is based in Irving, Texas.

entry.author: By Adam Haigh
entry.headline: Goldman Sachs Turns Bullish on European Banks as Sovereign-Debt Risk Eases
entry.body:
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. turned bullish on European banks for the first time since September 2009 as concern about the region''s sovereign-debt crisis eased and the industry remained among the cheapest.

The U.S. bank that makes the most revenue from trading advised investors to take an overweight position on banks, raising its previous neutral recommendation, according to a group of equity strategists led Peter Oppenheimer. Investors should pay for the trade by lowering holdings of consumer shares, he wrote.

For financials the narrowing of sovereign spreads in peripheral eurozone, which our economists expect to continue, is a clear positive, London-based Oppenheimer wrote in the report dated Feb. 3. Banks are one of the least expensive sectors in the market and the trade-off between their growth prospects and earnings in the next few years looks especially attractive.

The Stoxx Europe 600 Index, a regional benchmark, has rallied 23 percent since a low in May 2010 amid optimism that the U.S. economy is strengthening and as European governments implemented policies to support indebted countries using the single currency.

entry.author: By Nariman Gizitdinov
entry.headline: Chevron''s Kazakh Venture Triples Crude Extraction Tax Payments
entry.body:
Chevron Corp.''s Kazakh oil venture more than tripled crude extraction tax payments as the government seeks a larger share of resource revenue.

The TengizChevroil venture, Kazakhstan''s biggest crude exporter, paid 445 billion tenge ($3 billion) in oil extraction taxes last year, compared with 122 billion tenge in 2009, the Finance Ministry''s Tax Committee said on its website. The payments do not include export duties, Raikhan Sharipova, an Astana-based spokeswoman for the committee, said today by phone.

Kazakhstan, which holds 3 percent of the world''s oil reserves according to BP Plc, introduced the extraction tax in 2009, replacing royalties, as it sought to boost revenue and narrowed a budget deficit. In August 2010, the government started levying export taxes on crude oil pumped under 146 contracts, including Chevron''s venture.

TengizChevroil increased oil production to 19 million tons in the first nine months, compared with 22.5 million tons it produced in 2009, according to the company''s website.

The venture''s total tax burden more than doubled to 991 billion tenge last year from 452 billion tenge in 2009, the tax committee said. The venture paid 512 billion tenge in corporate income tax, compared with 294 billion tenge in 2009.

TengizChevroil made over $8 billion in payments to Kazakhstan in 2010, Novosti-Kazakhstan reported on Feb. 2, citing General Director Tim Miller. Linsi Crain, an Atyrau-based spokeswoman for TengizChevroil, didn''t answer her office phone or replay to a message seeking comment.

Chevron, based in San Ramon, California, holds 50 percent of TengizChevroil. Exxon Mobil Corp. has 25 percent, state-run KazMunaiGaz National Co. owns 20 percent and Lukarco, owned by Russia''s OAO Lukoil, 5 percent.

entry.author: By Francois de Beaupuy
entry.headline: General Mills, Axa, Nestle May Make Yoplait Bids, Echos Says
entry.body:
Fourteen investors have shown interest in the 50 percent stake in French dairy products maker Yoplait SAS that PAI Partners wants to sell, including General Mills Inc. and Nestle SA, Les Echos reported, without citing anyone.

Private-equity firm PAI will accept initial offers from today, the newspaper said.

Other bidders may include Mexican foodmaker Grupo Lala SA, buyout funds Lion Capital LLP, Axa Private Equity, and Bain Capital LLC, Les Echos added. KKR and the Chinese companies Bright Foods and Bright Dairy may also bid, the newspaper said.

Nestle may partner with French dairy product maker Groupe Lactalis, whose 1.38 billion-euro ($1.88 billion) bid for 100 percent of Yoplait was rejected last year, Les Echos said. The French sovereign fund, FSI, may also seek a stake in Yoplait, the newspaper reported.

entry.author: By Dakin Campbell
entry.headline: Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Said to Be Among Ally''s IPO Underwriters
entry.body:
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and JPMorgan Chase Co. are among four New York-based firms picked by Ally Financial Inc. to manage its initial public offering, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

Ally, the auto lender majority owned by the U.S. government, also selected Citigroup Inc. and Morgan Stanley, said the person, who declined to be identified because the decision isn''t public. The U.S. Treasury Department, which owns 73.8 percent of the lender, will decide how much the underwriters are paid, the person said.

Ally chose the underwriters after interviewing banks last week as Chief Executive Officer Michael Carpenter, 63, positions the company for an IPO and the government looks to begin unwinding its stake. The size of the offering hasn''t been decided, the person said.

Gina Proia, a spokeswoman for Detroit-based Ally, declined to comment, as did spokespeople for the four banks. Earlier this week, Ally reported a fourth straight quarterly profit, posting $79 million in net income for the fourth quarter.

Citigroup and Goldman Sachs have previously advised Ally. Last March, Ally was said to hire both banks to explore ways to repay U.S. taxpayers, and helped consider strategic alternatives for its mortgage unit, which is now complete.

JPMorgan was chosen to participate in the share sales for General Motors Co., American International Group Inc. and now Ally, all of which have stakes owned by the U.S. government. JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs were among those picked to manage the AIG offering, a person with direct knowledge of the decision said on Jan. 18. JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley and Citigroup were among the firms that helped handle GM''s sale.

Underwriting Fees

The banks are unlikely to earn typical underwriting fees, based on other transactions involving government ownership. Treasury''s acting assistant secretary for financial stability, Tim Massad, said Jan. 19 that underwriting fees in the AIG sale will be very low by normal standards and that they won''t be any higher than GM. GM paid 0.75 percent in fees to banks managing its IPO.

Ally, a former GM unit once called GMAC Inc., benefited from three rounds of government aid totaling $17.2 billion. In addition to U.S. taxpayers, so-called third-party investors own 8.5 percent, Cerberus Capital Management LP has about 7.8 percent and GM and an affiliated trust hold 9.9 percent.

entry.author: By Dan Hart
entry.headline: Exxon Beaumont Chemical Plant Fault Causes Gases to Flare
entry.body:
Exxon Mobil Corp. said an unknown incident caused emissions at its Beaumont, Texas, chemical plant, according to a filing with the National Response Center.

About 10 pounds (4 kilograms) each of butadiene and benzene and 1,000 pounds of nitrogen oxide were released at 5:45 a.m. local time yesterday, according to the filing.

entry.author: By Jason Webb
entry.headline: Pfizer''s Closing of Research Office Will Hurt U.K., Times Says
entry.body:
Pfizer Inc.''s decision to close a U.K. research office will damage the country''s standing in research, the Sunday Times reported, citing an interview with Simon Campbell, a retired scientist who helped Pfizer develop the impotence drug Viagra.

Scientists employed at the office in Sandwich, England, will struggle to find new jobs, Campbell said, according to Times.
